lesson.title: The Web and HTML
lesson.summary: In this lesson, we'll be exploring how to create web pages—and, along the way, you'll learn some important concepts about how computer languages work.

question.prompt: Which of these descriptions most accurately describes the Web?

answers.text: A single large server that is run by Facebook and Google
HTML documents and other resources that refer to each other with links
Programs and games that run on the Windows operating system
A pattern of psychic waves in the Earth's magnetosphere

atoms.text:
## Practice — Introduction
Throughout this course, we'll ask you a lot of questions. The purpose of these questions is not to _test_ you or see if you're smart enough—rather, the point is to strengthen the new connections you are building in your brain.

question.prompt: What is the main language that we use to write **web pages**?

atoms.text: Sometimes the questions we ask will seem too easy, and other times they may be very challenging.  Try not to worry too much about whether a question is easy or hard. Just try your best, and then read any feedback you get so that you can improve!

question.prompt: What is **hypertext**?

answers.text: Any text that can be displayed on a computer.
Any text that can be displayed in a web browser.
Text that can have references (such as links) to other documents and resources.

atoms.text:
## Thinking ahead ...
Again, don't worry if you don't get the right answer to a question the first time. In some cases, we will even ask you questions about things we haven't explained yet!

Research has shown that when you try to solve a problem, this effort by itself helps you learn better — even when you don't succeed at getting the answer. By actively thinking about the problem and _trying_ to figure it out, you are priming your brain for a much better level of understanding.

question.prompt: Take a guess—what do you think the **H** in **HTML** stands for?

complex_prompt.text:
On the next page, we're going to talk a little about how _web pages_ and _web browsers_ work.

It can help to get your brain thinking about an idea before it's explained to you. So you may not know the answer, but give it a little thought and try to decide if each of these statements is true or false:

concepts.text: A **web browser** is an application, like _Chrome_, _Firefox_, _Edge_, or _Safari_, that is designed for displaying **web pages**.
A **server** is a special computer that is **totally different** from your personal computer.
**All** of the things you see on a web page have to be stored on the **same server** (you can't have different parts of a web page on different servers).
Usually, to load a **web page**, your browser sends a request for that page to a **server**.

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Web Pages And Servers

question.prompt:
Which of these statements do you think are true about Udacity's web site?

(Select **all** the statements that are true.)

answers.text: When you type `udacity.com` into your browser, your browser communicates with Udacity's server using HTTP (or HTTPS).
Udacity's web server returns an HTML file to your browser.
Your browser copies all of the files stored on Udacity's web server onto your computer.
Based on information contained in the HTML, your browser requests other files from Udacity's web server and from other web servers.
Everything displayed on Udacity's web site has to come from Udacity's web server.

atoms.text: ## Practice — Web pages and servers

complex_prompt.text: Mark whether each of these statements is **True** or **False**.

concepts.text: When you go to a page on the Web, your browser sends a request to a server.
HTML stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol.
HTTP stands for Hypertext Markup Language.
A web page can include resources (like videos or images) from multiple web servers.

question.prompt: Why do web addresses usually contain `http:` or `https:` at the beginning?

answers.text: This tells the browser that the page is written in HTML.
This tells the browser that the page is written in English.
This tells the browser which rules (or _protocol_) to use when talking to the web server.

question.prompt: Suppose that you are working on a new web page on your own computer. What do you need to do to be able to see this web page displayed in your browser as you work on it?

answers.text: Put the file on a web server and then load it in the browser.
Simply save the file on your own computer and then load it in the browser.
Write an email to yourself and include the web page as an attachment.
Load the web page up in a word processor, such as Microsoft Word or LibreOffice.

question.prompt: You've made a spiffy new web page, and you're ready to share it with the world. What do you need to do so that other people can access it?

answers.text: Put the file on a web server.
Load the file in your browser.
Write an email to everyone in the world and attach the page to it.
Upload a `.doc` file to your favorite social media site.

question.prompt: What does **HTML** stand for?
What does **HTTP** stand for?

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: HTML and Programming

atoms.text:
The Mozilla Developer Network is a major resource for web developers. Find it here:
* https://developer.mozilla.org/

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Text editors and files

atoms.text:
## Installing a text editor
If you don't have a text editor installed on your computer already, you'll need to get one now in order to follow along with us for the rest of this course. Here are a couple we recommend:

* [Atom](https://atom.io/) is a popular editor created by the folks at GitHub. It is available for Windows, Mac, Linux, and other systems.
* [VS Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) is another very popular editor, created at Microsoft. It is also available for Windows, Mac, and Linux.

tasks: I've installed **Atom**, **VS Code**, or another code editor.

atoms.text:
## ⚠️Caution!

Don't try to write your code in a **word processor** (like _Microsoft Word_, _Pages_, _Google Docs_, or _TextEdit_). These applications can add extra hidden formatting data to the text. Although the code may _look_ fine, this additional hidden data can cause errors that prevent the code from working!

question.prompt:
Which of these kinds of files are made of text?  
(Sellect **all** that apply.)

answers.text: A story that you wrote in the Atom editor
A piece of recorded music on your phone
The HTML for the Udacity home page
A photo of a dog doing a silly trick
A PDF file of a legal contract

atoms.text:
## Start a `notes.html` file!

Now that you've installed a text editor, use it to create an HTML file. Specifically, let's create a file called `notes.html` that you can use to take notes throughout this course.

Taking notes in this file will serve two purposes. First, as you go through the course, you can test out your knowledge of HTML, by writing HTML code in this file and displaying it in your browser. And second, the act of writing down the ideas will help you remember them better — and if you do forget something, you can simply look at your notes!

**Later on, at the very end of this lesson, you'll submit your notes file to our automatic grading system and we'll check your HTML code!**

tasks: In your text editor, create a new file and write some text in it  (such as `My HTML notes`).
Save the file with the name `notes.html`. You can save it to your desktop, or to another folder if you prefer.
Make sure that you actually type the `.html` extension when you save the file!
Open the file in your web browser. You can do this by double-clicking on the file (wherever you saved it) or by dragging the file into your browser.

atoms.text: You should now have something that looks like this, with the `notes.html` file open in both your code editor _and_ your web browser:

atoms.alt: Screenshot: A text editor on the left and a browser on the right.

atoms.text: If you make a change to the text in your code editor, you'll be able to see this change in the browser—but not right away. First, you'll need to **save** the file in your code editor, and then **refresh** the page in your browser.

tasks: Make a small change to the text in your **notes.html** file.
**Save** the file again.
**Refresh** the page in your browser—you should now see the change you made!
atoms.positive_feedback:
**Great!**

Now you can use this file to take notes and try out your code!

atoms.text:
By the way, you'll be doing this a lot—**saving** your code and **refreshing** the web browser to see the change. So you may want to use the hotkeys for these actions. Pressing **Ctrl + S** (on Windows) or **⌘S** (on Mac) will save your file in most editors. And pressing **Ctrl + R** (Windows) or **⌘R** (Mac) will refresh the browser.

As a review, here's another take on setting up your programming environment for HTML:

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: The Job of HTML

question.prompt:
Which pieces of text follow the rules we have just described for HTML tags?

(Select **all** the correct answers.)
Which one of these terms describes the text `<em>` in an HTML file?

atoms.title: Update your notes file!
tasks: Open up your `notes.html` file in your text editor.
As best as you can, try to explain what **markup** is.
Use the `em` element to italicize something.
Save the file and open it up in your web browser (to see the changes).
atoms.positive_feedback: Great! Keeping notes will help you learn, and you'll turn in your notes at the end of this lesson.

atoms.text: ## Practice — Markup

complex_prompt.text: Match each piece of HTML with its description.

question.prompt: Technically, `Hello!` is an **element**, while `` and `` are **tags**. Which of these statements is true?

answers.text: Developers almost always use these terms in the technically correct way.
Developers often say "element" when they mean "tag", and vice versa.

atoms.text: ## Thinking ahead ...

question.prompt: Here's some HTML: ```html Did you know? Spaces, tabs, and line breaks are called whitespace. ``` And here's some more: ```html Did you know? Spaces, tabs, and line breaks are called whitespace. ``` If you rendered these two examples in a browser, would they look any different from each other? Take a guess—or try them out and see for yourself!

answers.text: They would look exactly the same.

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Breaks And Empty Elements

atoms.text:
**Whitespace** includes spaces, tabs, and line breaks. When the browser displays an HTML file, it treats a run of whitespace as a single space character. In order to create a line break that will show up in the browser, use the `
` tag.

tasks: Add break tags so that the poem is displayed on multiple lines instead of one.
atoms.positive_feedback: **Great!** As you continue in this lesson, you will use many, many more HTML tags.
atoms.description: In the workspace below, you can try out the break tag for yourself. Try editing the HTML in the text editor on the left side of the screen. A few seconds later, the browser display on the right side will update!

tasks: Add a paragraph tag.
Add another!
atoms.description: In the workspace below, add paragraph tags to the story. You'll see the results on the right-hand side!

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks:
Update your `notes.html` file. Use `

` and `

` tags to separate your notes into different paragraphs.
Make sure to save your file and open it in your browser to check it!
atoms.positive_feedback: Paragraphs definitely look better than running all the text together into one big block, don't they?

atoms.text: ## Practice — Midpoint review

complex_prompt.text:
Suppose you wanted to display a series of paragraphs on a web page, with some space in between each one — something like this:

>First paragraph.
>
>Second paragraph.
>
>Yay, we like space!

Which of these pieces of HTML would work for this?

concepts.text:
```html
First paragraph.

Second paragraph.

Yay, we like space!
```

```html First paragraph.

Second paragraph.

Yay, we like space!

```

```html First paragraph.
Second paragraph.
Yay, we like space!
```

question.prompt: Of the two correct options from the last exercise, which one would generally be better?

answers.text: The one that used the `p` element.
The one that used the `br` element.

complex_prompt.text: Match each of these terms with its meaning.

concepts.text: The grammar rules of a language.
The idea that some bits of code can go inside other bits of code.
Code that tells the browser what the text on a web page should look like.
Text that can have links or references.
A general term for spaces, tabs, and line breaks.

question.prompt:
Which of these applications would work for writing code?
(One of these options we didn't really talk about directly—but take your best guess!)

There are **two** correct answers on this exercise.

answers.text: A code editor, like **Atom** or **VS Code**.
A **word processor**, such as **Word**, **Pages**, **Google Docs**, or **TextEdit**.
A text editor that uses only **plain text**, such as **Notepad**.

complex_prompt.text: What kind of a thing is each of these pieces of HTML?
Here's a piece of HTML: ```html Aah! I'm confused about whitespace. ``` Which of the pieces of HTML below would give exactly the same results as this one, once they are rendered in a browser?

question.prompt: When programmers say "computers are stupid," what do they really mean?

answers.text: That computers don't have the same level of *computational complexity* as the *human brain* does.
That computers do things so fast, the *extreme speed* of their computations causes them to *make mistakes.*
That computers take code *completely literally*; if you make a typo, the computer *will not guess* at what you _really_ meant.

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Lots of elements

question.prompt: What do the `sub` and `sup` elements do? Try them out in your text editor and browser.

answers.text: They make the text larger so you can read it on a **sub**marine or if you're **Sup**erman.
They flip the text upside-down and right-side-up again.
They make the text into a **sub**liminal message that's **sup**er-sneaky.
They move the text vertically, as **sub**script or **sup**erscript.

question.prompt: Which example has correctly nested elements?

atoms.title: Check your notes!
tasks: I've checked my notes file for nesting problems.
atoms.positive_feedback: As you keep taking notes, make sure to follow the nesting rules!
atoms.description: This is a good time to check your `notes.html` file to make sure that you're using nested tags correctly. Look through the HTML elements you've written there and check that they are following the nesting rules!

atoms.text:
# HTML Elements Review 1 Here are the HTML elements that you've seen so far in this course. If you haven't tried them out yet in your own text editor and browser, this is a great time to do it! * `` and `` — Emphasis. By default, text inside `` is displayed as _italic_, and text in `` is displayed as **boldface.** * `

` — Paragraph. Text in a paragraph is separated visually from other paragraphs by a small margin. * `
` — Line break. _(empty)_ A line break does not create a new paragraph; it only marks the end of a line. * `` and `` — Subscript and superscript. Useful for math and chemistry: I have x3+2x2 molecules of H2O. * `` — Highlighting. Not very often used, but it's kind of cool. Of these elements, the `br` element is the only one that is an empty (or void) element. **Download this review as a PDF by clicking on the `IPND Reference Sheet - HTML Elements 1` link at the bottom of the page!**

question.prompt:
Do some research on your own using your favorite search engine!

Which of these HTML elements can be used for headlines, or section headings, in a document?

atoms.text:
## Practice — Headings As you just discovered, the `h1` element can be used for **headlines**, or **section headings**. There are actually six of these heading elements: `h1` through `h6`. >

I'm an `h1` heading

I'm an `h2` heading

I'm an `h3` heading

I'm an `h4` heading

I'm an `h5` heading
I'm an `h6` heading
`h1` is used for the main heading on a page, while the rest are used for sub-headings. Something you might notice about the above examples is that, like with the `p` element, heading elements create a little bit of space (margin) around themselves. In the workspace below, try them out! Note that we _haven't_ shown you the syntax, but it's similar to other elements you've tried. If you get really stuck, try Googling it, or check out our solution below the workspace. See if you can replicate this design: >

My HTML Notes

>

This page is a collection of my awesome notes about HTML!

>

The Web

>

The Web (or World Wide Web) is a collection of documents and other files. Most of the documents are made using Hypertext Markup Language (HTML).

>

What is HTML?

>

HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language. It's used to define the structure or layout of a web page.

Notice that there's one main heading, followed by two sub-headings that are the same size.

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution ```html

My HTML Notes

This page is a collection of my awesome notes about HTML!

The Web

The Web (or World Wide Web) is a collection of documents and other files. Most of the documents are made using Hypertext Markup Language (HTML).

What is HTML?

HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language. It's used to define the structure or layout of a web page.

``` **Note:** You may have noticed that you don't actually _have_ to use the `p` element as shown in our solution here. But like we mentioned earlier, it's a good idea to tell the browser what kind of content something is—by enclosing those paragraphs inside `p` elements, this is indicating that the contents are paragraphs of text. We'll explain more about _why_ this matters in the next lesson, when you learn about something called CSS.
## Practice — Elements review 1

complex_prompt.text: Match each HTML element with what it does.
And here are some more elements to match up!

concepts.text: Visually separates a piece of text from the other things around it.
Makes a headline, or section header, in a document.

atoms.text:
In the workspace below, you'll find some notes that I took—but the text has no formatting and is hard to read! See if you can add the correct HTML elements to make the text look something like this: >

My chemistry notes

Molecule name: Sulfur hexafluoride

Molecular formula: C6H12O6

Note: This gas has a much higher density than air. Basically the opposite of helium. Crazy!

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution Here's one way to do it. Your markup might look a little different! ```html

My chemistry notes

Molecule name: Sulfur hexafluoride

Molecular formula: C6H12O6

Note: This gas has a much higher density than air. Basically the opposite of helium. Crazy!

```

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Block And Inline

atoms.text:
## For your reference ...

If you want to check it out, here is a full list of all of the block and inline elements in HTML.

Block-level elements — https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Block-level_elements#Elements

Inline elements — https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Inline_elements#Elements
## Practice — Block and inline

question.prompt: Which of these statements is true?

answers.text: `br` is a **block** element, meaning the browser creates an invisible box around the text.

When you put a `
` tag at the end of a line, this causes the browser to create a space or _margin_ around the left and right sides of the text.
`p` is a **block** element, meaning the browser creates an invisible box around the text.

complex_prompt.text: Which of these elements are **block** and which are **inline**?

atoms.text:
It can seem a bit abstract trying to imagine these "invisible boxes" that the browser constructs around the elements. So in this next workspace, we've added some style code that makes some of the boxes visible by giving them a border. 

Don't worry about understanding the style code itself right now—we'll get into the details of how this works in the next lesson, when we talk about CSS. For now, we've just added it to help you actually _see_ that there really are boxes constructed by the browser.

Just like in the video on the last page, the upper example uses the `br` element to split the text to multiple lines, whereas the lower example uses the `p` element. As you can see, the `br` element has no box—it's _just_ a line break. In contrast, the `p` element has a box, and you can see the margin that the browser is adding just outside the border, which creates some space between one paragraph and the next.

**You don't have to do anything specific here, but if you like, you can play with this by adding additional paragraphs or breaks.**

## Practice — The `div` element In the video on block and inline elements, you may (or may not) have noticed that one of the block-level elements Kelly mentioned was called `div`. The `div` is short for **division**, because that's what this element is for—you can use it to _divide_ up the page into different sections. Like the paragraph `p` element, the division `div` element has an invisible box around it—and just like `p`, it can have a border, a margin, a width, a height, and so on. But a `p` element is specifically meant to contain text. In contrast, the `div` element is a _generic_ container for whatever other elements you might want to put inside. You can use the `div` element to organize the content and divide the page into sections. That's a bit abstract. It might help to give it a try in the workspace below. Try nesting the last two paragraphs inside a `div` element, like this: ```html

Call me Ishmael.

Just don't call me late for dinner.

``` We've set the `div` element's border to appear as well (in blue), so you should be able to see that the `p` elements are contained _inside_ the `div`, like this:

atoms.alt: A blue box containing two lines of text, each in its own red box.

atoms.text: The `div` element is a super important one, and it's used a _lot_ in HTML to help lay out and organize pages. We aren't going to use the `div` element much in this lesson, but we'll be coming back to it in the next lesson—so keep it in mind!

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Lists And Implied Close Tags

atoms.text:
The `p` element is another example of an element for which the closing tag is optional. You can include the closing tag: ```html

Like this!

``` Or leave it off: ```html

Like this! ``` Remember, when you leave off an optional closing tag, it is still _implied_—that is, the browser will figure out where the element should be closed, even though you didn't explicitly tell it.

question.prompt:
Here's some HTML for creating a list: ```html
  • Thing one
  • Thing two
``` What do you think this list will look like in the browser?

atoms.text:
In the workspace below, see if you can write the HTML for this list:

1. Learn HTML.
2. Learn CSS.
3. Learn Python.
4. Save the world.

**If you get stuck, you can find our solution below the workspace.**

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution Here is a solution to the exercise in the workspace above the quizzes. Remember, the closing tag on the `li` element is optional. So you can include them or leave them off and it will work the same either way. Here it is with the closing tags: ```html
  1. Learn HTML.
  2. Learn CSS.
  3. Learn Python.
  4. Save the world.
``` And here it is without the closing tags on the list items—but notice that the closing tag on the list element `ol` is _not_ optional, so we have to include that either way. ```html
  1. Learn HTML.
  2. Learn CSS.
  3. Learn Python.
  4. Save the world.
``` >**Note:** Pay attention to the fact that the closing tag is optional for `li`, but **not** optional for `ol` and `ul`. In other words, a closing tag is optional for each list item, but not for the list as a whole. We must be sure to close the list as a whole! Why? Because if we leave off the closing `` or ``, then the browser will not know when our list ends! It will simply treat everything that comes after that point as part of the list.

question.prompt:
Which of these pieces of HTML are **missing** a required closing tag?  
(Select **all** that apply.)
Which of these pieces of HTML has a closing tag that it **should not**?

answers.text:
`

Billy Mack is a detective down in Texas

`

`
You know he knows just exactly what the facts is
`

`

But I'm not sure that "Texas" rhymes with "facts is".

`

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks: Add an ordered list (`ol`).
Add an unordered list (`ul`).
Which two elements (that you've learned about so far) have optional closing tags?
When you leave off a closing tag, how does the browser know when to close that element?
atoms.positive_feedback:
**Great!**

`p` and `li` are the two elements you've seen with optional closing tags. And the browser knows there has to be a closing tag when it gets to the start tag of a new element that can't be inside of the last one. For example, when it gets to the start of a new `p` element, it knows the previous `p` element must be closed.

When you put things in your own words, this helps you understand and remember the concepts better—but don't worry about making it perfect. If you're a little unsure of something, just take a shot at it. This effort by itself will help you develop your understanding when you encounter that concept again.
atoms.description:
Update your `notes.html` file to try out lists—and to explain some of the concepts you just learned.

Here are some specific things to try, and some specific questions to answer:

atoms.text:
## Nested lists

Here's a simple list with no nesting:
* Mammals
* Reptiles
* Birds

In the workspace below, see if you can nest additional lists _inside_ this one, in order to create the following:

* Mammals
 1. Raccoons
 2. Gorillas
* Reptiles
 1. Iguanas
 2. Cobras
* Birds
 1. Ostriches
 2. Ravens

You'll know you have it right when the right-hand side of the workspace looks like the list above!

**If you get stuck, you can check out our solution below the workspace.**

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution Here is a solution to the nested list exercise above. Remember, the closing `` tags are optional. Here we've left them out, but if you included them in your code that also works fine! (But, again, the closing `` and `` tags are not optional—make sure to include those!) ```html
  • Mammals
    1. Raccoons
    2. Gorillas
  • Reptiles
    1. Iguanas
    2. Cobras
  • Birds
    1. Ostriches
    2. Ravens
```

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks: Add a nested list to your `notes.html` file.
atoms.positive_feedback:
**Great!**

We hope you find the note-taking useful!

atoms.text: ## Practice — Indentation

question.prompt:
Here's a short block of HTML code: ```html

Does indentation matter?

``` And here's another: ```html

Does indentation matter?

``` And one more: ```html

Does indentation matter?

``` If you were to render these examples in a browser, would they look any different?

answers.text: Yes — all three would give **different** results.
No — all three would give the exact **same** result.

atoms.text:
You may have noticed that code editors sometimes try to help you out with your indentation. For example, when you hit the _enter_ key, editors will sometimes insert an indent at the beginning of the new line. Usually this default indentation is good, but sometimes it goes wrong. For example, when you leave off the optional closing tag on a list item `li`, many code editors will indent to the right because they think you're wanting to nest something _inside_ that `li`. That can lead to patterns like this: ```html
  • Yikes!
  • This
  • keeps
  • indenting
  • to the right!
``` When that happens, you may have to manually delete some of the extra indentation to clean things up.

complex_prompt.text: Which of these examples are indented well and which are indented poorly?

atoms.text:
In the workspace below, you'll see the same nested list that you created a little while ago. As you can see on the right, the code renders fine. But if you look at the code on the left ... ugh! 😱 Whoever wrote this didn't make any effort to make it readable.

Can you add indentation to make it easier to read?

When you're done, you can compare your code with our solution below.

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution **Note:** There isn't a single "correct" way that you _have_ to use when indenting your HTML code—and different people often have somewhat different opinions on what to indent when. So don't worry if your code doesn't match ours exactly. That said, there _are_ some conventions that can help you decide when to indent and when not to. If you're curious about these conventions and the reasons for them, you can find a nice discussion of the topic [here](https://www.granneman.com/webdev/coding/formatting-and-indenting-your-html). ```html

Here is an example of a nested list:

  • Mammals
    1. Raccoons
    2. Gorillas
  • Reptiles
    1. Iguanas
    2. Cobras
  • Birds
    1. Ostriches
    2. Ravens

Indentation can help show the nested structure of the elements.

It can also make the code much easier to read!

```

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks: The indentation in my `notes.html` file is generally organized and consistent.
I've used indentation to help show which elements are nested _inside_ other elements.
atoms.description:
Now would be a good time to check the indentation in your notes file and adjust it if things are looking a bit messy or inconsistent.

And remember, indentation can help you see which elements are nested _inside_ other elements. So take advantage of that to make the code more readable!

atoms.text: ## Practice — Implied close tags
Have a quick look at the HTML in the workspace below. Then, see if you can answer the questions about it (below the workspace).

You'll notice something new in this code: `style="color: blue;"`.

As you can see, this turns the entire contents of the second `p` element blue.

We'll explain how this works in detail in the next lesson—for now, it's just there to help you better see how the closing tag on that `p` element works.

question.prompt:
Like we mentioned above, all of the contents of the second `p` element are blue. What happens to the text color if you delete the closing `

` tag from the second `p` element? (Try it in the workspace and see!)

answers.text: Since the element is never closed, all of the text for the rest of the page gets turned blue.

Nothing changes—the browser knows that the element should be closed in the exact same place, even if the `

` isn't there.

All the text up to the next `

` tag gets turned blue.

question.prompt: What happens if you delete the closing `` tag?

answers.text: Since the element is never closed, all of the text for the rest of the page ends up in **bold**.
Nothing changes—the browser knows that the element should be closed, even if the `` isn't there.

question.prompt: Why doesn't the `br` element require a closing tag?

answers.text: Because the closing tag is optional, just like with the `p` element.
Because, unlike the `p` element,  the `br` element has no contents.

atoms.title: Intro to HTML:  Web Addresses, or URLs

atoms.text:
As Kelly noted at the end of the video: When you're linking to the top page (or home page) of a site, the URL does not need a file path after the domain name—so you will just see a single slash at the end of the address:

```
http://en.wikipedia.org/
```

And often this slash will be omitted altogether:

```
http://en.wikipedia.org
```

This would still be considered a fully-qualified URL.

In contrast, if we look at the URL for a file on your local system, we *must* give the file path—in fact, most of the URL *is* the file path:

```
file:///Users/Kelly/notes.html
```

If we took away the file path from the above, we would just have:

```
file://
```

Which is definitely *not* a fully qualified URL.

question.prompt: Which of these addresses is a fully qualified URL that can be used in HTML?

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Links And The A Tag

question.prompt: Think back to earlier in the lesson, when you learned about **block** and **inline** elements. Do you think the `a` element is block or inline? If you're not sure, just take your best guess (or Google it!).
Write an HTML `a` element with the URL "https://github.com/" and the contents **GitHub**.

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks: Add a link to your favorite web site!
atoms.description: Update your `notes.html` file using what you've learned.

atoms.text: ## Practice — Addresses and links

complex_prompt.text:
Here are two examples of URLs:

```html
http://example.net/stuff.html
file:///Users/Karl/courses/kittens.jpg
```

Can you label the different parts?

question.answers_label: What kind of thing is it?

complex_prompt.text: Here's a line of HTML that creates a hyperlink: ```html Example Page ``` Below, we've chopped this line up—see if you can name what kind of a thing each piece is.

question.answers_label: What kind of thing is it?

correct_answer.text: contents (what the user actually clicks on)

answers.text: contents (what the user actually clicks on)

question.prompt: Your friend puts this anchor element in their web page: ```html The Example Page ``` They want this link to go to the Google home page. Which of these statements is true?

answers.text: The link won't work, because it doesn't use a fully qualified URL
The link will work, because it _does_ use a fully qualified URL
The link will work, but fully qualified URLs aren't necessary in hyperlinks

question.prompt: What could your friend add to their anchor element to make it work?

answers.text: Add `https://` to the beginning of the URL.
Add a file path to the end of the URL.
Remove the `/` from the end of the URL.

question.prompt: Write a piece of HTML that will display the image `https://fakeurl.example.net/fish.png` with the alt text "Fish".

atoms.title: An image that is a link

question.prompt: Many websites have images that are also links: the browser displays an image, but then the user can click on that image to go to a different page. Which of these approaches do you think is used to create these?

answers.text: Put an `img` element inside an `a` element, between the open and close tags
Put an `a` element inside an `img` element
Put an `img` element after the close tag of an `a` element (i.e. after the `` tag)
You can't do it in HTML; doing this requires JavaScript.

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Files And Relative URLs

question.prompt:
Which of these `img` elements uses a relative URL?  
(Select **all** that apply.)
Which of these `a` tags will create a working link to Google?

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks: Add an `img` element to the HTML of your notes file.
Load your notes file in a browser to make sure the image appears.
Be sure to include `alt` text on your image element!
atoms.description:
Now that you know how to use the `img` element, you can use it to display an image in your notes!

If you like, you can use one of the images that Karl showed in the video, like `https://placebear.com/800/600`—or you can find your own image and use that instead!

atoms.text: ## Practice — Images and relative URLs

question.prompt: Here's some HTML for making a link: ```html Google ``` And here's some for displaying an image: ```html ``` What kind of a thing are `href="https://www.google.com"`, `src="kittens.jpg"`, and `alt="Kittens!"`?

Karl is working on his `notes.html` file. When he loads the page in a browser, the URL shows up as:

```html
file:///Users/Karl/Documents/Udacity/notes.html
```
Which of these statements is true?

answers.text: The URL tells us that Karl's `notes.html` file is available online (it's on a Web server).
The URL tells us that Karl's `notes.html` file is stored on his computer in a folder named Udacity, which is inside his Documents folder.
The URL tells us that Karl's `notes.html` file is stored on his computer in a folder named Documents, which is inside his Udacity folder.

question.prompt: Karl still has his `notes.html` file in the same location from the previous question. Suppose he now adds an image to his page, using the following `img` element: ```html ``` As you can see, this gives the location of the image as a _relative_ URL. Where will the browser look for the file?

answers.text: Somewhere on the Web. It's impossible to say where for sure.
In the same folder as `notes.html`—that is, `/Users/Karl/Documents/Udacity/kittens.jpg`

question.prompt: What can you say about this link? `Learn to code!`

answers.text: This link will work fine—it's missing part of the URL, but that's OK because the browser will figure it out.
This link won't work because the element has no contents.
This link won't work—since there is no `://`, the browser will interpret this as a _relative_ URL, and think that `udacity.com` is the name of a file.

question.prompt:
Your friend sends you an HTML file, all by itself, with some `img` elements in it. Your friend did _not_ send you any image files along with the HTML file.

Indicate which of their `img` elements (listed below) will work and display an image when you open their page in your browser.

answers.text: ` `
``
``
``

question.prompt:
You have an image of your pet octopus Zeke, called `zeke.png`. You've saved the image file in the same folder as your web page.

Write an `img` element to display this image on your web page. Make sure to include the alternate text attribute, with the description, `A picture of my pet octopus, Zeke.`.

atoms.text:
Sometimes when you're working on a Web page, you don't know what images you're going to use, but you still want a picture to use as a place holder. 

Websites like [placebear.com](https://placebear.com) and [placekitten.com](https://placekitten.com) are designed to make this super easy. All you have to do to get an image of any given size is put the width and height of the image at the end of the URL, as in `https://placebear.com/200/300`.

You can play with this in the workspace below!

If you enjoyed playing with those, you can find other similar sites by doing a search for "image placeholder" and you'll find that there are gazillions more of them out there—like [Lorem Picsum](https://picsum.photos/) and [FillMurray.com](https://www.fillmurray.com/)

# HTML elements review 2 Now you've learned about many more HTML elements! This page is a summary of all the elements you've seen so far. You can use this page as a reference if you forget how to use one of these elements in your code. ## Block elements Block elements are used for large sections of text, such as paragraphs, headlines, or lists; and also for some other features such as video players and tables. A block element creates a (usually invisible) box in the browser display. By default, this box takes up the full width of the display. The beginning of a block always starts on a new line in the display. Most block elements have a particular way they are displayed by default: paragraphs have margins around them; lists have bullet-points or numbered items; headlines are printed in large text. There is also a generic block element, `div`, which has no special defaults. * `p` — Paragraph. Text in a paragraph is separated visually from other paragraphs by a small margin. * `ul` and `ol` — Unordered and ordered lists. By default, `ul` lists are displayed with bullet points, and `ol` lists with numbered items. * `li` — List items inside a `ul` or `ol` list. The `li` element has to be nested inside a `ul` or `ol` list; it can't occur on its own. * Section headers, from `h1` (largest) to `h6` (smallest). Used for headlines, section titles, and the like. * `div` — A logical *div*ision of a page or document. Other block elements such as paragraphs, lists, and headers can be nested inside a `div`. You will see the `div` element much more in the next lesson. Because they don't have any default display settings, `div`s are heavily used with custom styling with CSS. ## Inline elements Inline elements do not create a full-width box on the display. They modify the display of text, or insert other things into the text — such as line breaks, images, or hyperlinks. * `em` and `strong` — Emphasis. By default, text inside an `em` is displayed as _italic_, and text in `strong` is displayed as **boldface.** * `br` — Line break. _(empty)_ A line break does not create a new paragraph; it only marks the end of a line. * `sub` and `sup` — Subscript and superscript. Useful for math and chemistry: I have x3+2x2 molecules of H2O. * `mark` — Highlighting. Not very often used, but it's kind of cool. Some of the inline elements you've seen require **attributes**, extra information besides the name of the element itself. Attributes are written inside the opening tag of the element. * `img` — Images. Needs a `src` attribute with a URL, and an `alt` attribute with descriptive text. * `a` — Hyperlinks. Needs an `href` attribute with a URL. #### Images The syntax for the `img` tag is like this: ```html ``` The URL of an image may be an _absolute_ URL, such as `http://placebear.com/800/600`, or it may be a _relative_ URL such as `images/wolves.jpg`. The `alt` text is used if the image can't be loaded, or if the user can't see images — such as if the user is using a [screen reader](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_reader). #### Links Hyperlinks allow the user to navigate from one page to another. They are created using the `a` element. The destination of the link is written in an attribute called `href`; the link text appears as the contents of the `a` element. Here's an example: ```html Wikipedia's "Hypertext" article ``` This code produces a link like this: Wikipedia's "Hypertext" article. A link within a single web site can be written using a relative URL. Links to other sites must be written as absolute URLs. **Download this review as a PDF by clicking on the `IPND Reference Sheet - HTML Elements 2` link below!**
## Practice — Elements review 2

complex_prompt.text: Match each HTML element with what it does.

atoms.text:
In the workspace below, you can get some practice using the latest HTML elements you've learned. Try to reproduce the design shown below. Notice that the list items in this design are also hyperlinks! And if you click on one of them, it will open in a new browser tab. If you want to do this in your own links, you can add the attribute `target="_blank"` to the `a` element. Like this: ```html Example ``` We suggest doing that in this exercise, or else the link will open inside the workspace itself. For the images, you can use `https://placebear.com/150/150` and `https://placekitten.com/150/150`. >

My favorite things:

>
  1. Bears
  2. Kittens

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution Here's our code, if you want to compare: ```html

My favorite things:

  1. Bears
  2. Kittens
```

atoms.title: Intro to HTML:  Document Structure 1 - Doctype
Update your notes!
tasks: I've added `<!DOCTYPE html>` to the very top of my notes file.
atoms.positive_feedback: Great! There's one more thing you'll need to have a full HTML document. You'll learn it on the next page.
atoms.description: Now that you know about the DOCTYPE tag, add one to your notes file.

atoms.title: Intro to HTML:  Document Structure 2 - Body and head

question.prompt: Mark all the items that are **required** for a full HTML document.

answers.text: At least one image, with `alt` text describing it.
A `title` element with an open and close tag.
An `author` element with the name and email address of the author.

complex_prompt.text: Which of these HTML documents follows the rules you've just learned?

concepts.text:
```html My notes

I'm in the body!

```

```html

I'm in the head!

My notes ```

atoms.text:
## Are `head` and `body` required? In one sense, **no**, but in another sense, **yes.** The grammar of HTML does not require that you literally write a `` or `` tag in your HTML code. Many web developers do write these. However, if you *don't*, the browser will attempt to place them into your code itself. It needs to put the `head` element around certain elements that belong there, such as `title`; and to put the `body` element around the elements that form the document's body. This means that all the `head` elements must appear first, and the `body` elements after. You can't have a `head` element, such as `title`, in the middle of your document: ```html

Here is a 😨 problem:

This is a paragraph, which has to be part of the body. This is the title, which has to be part of the head.

The title is ❗️not allowed ❗️ to be in the middle of the body! ``` So even if you choose not to literally write the `` and `` _tags_ in your document, the `head` and `body` _elements_ are still created by the browser; and the rest of the document needs to be consistent with this. But you must make sure that the `title` and other `head` parts appear before any paragraphs, lists, images, or other `body` parts. > You might see older HTML documentation that says these tags are required. This was true in *XHTML*, an older version of HTML. Today's browsers use *HTML5*, which does not require them. In the next lesson, you will learn much more about how the browser understands and displays web pages, as you learn about Cascading Style Sheets.

atoms.title: Update your notes!
tasks: I've added`<html>`, `<head>`, and `<body>` elements to my notes file.
I've saved the file and opened it in my browser, to make sure it all still works.
atoms.positive_feedback: You now have a full HTML document!
atoms.description:
Now that you know about the `<html>`, `<head>`, and `<body>` elements, add them to your notes file. 

Everything in your page should fit into this overall structure:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <title>Title of your page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    Content goes here! (Things like paragraphs, links, and images.)
  </body>
</html>
```

You may also want to describe these elements a little. What are some examples of things that you might put in the `<head>`? How about the `<body>`? And what would go inside the `<html>` element?

Which of these things are required?

concepts.title: Practice — Parts of an HTML document

atoms.text:
## Practice — Parts of an HTML Document

When you're first learning HTML, some of the terms can easily get scrambled in your head. In particular, it's not uncommon to start mixing up terms like heading, head, title, and file name. So let's get some practice sorting out what is what.

For the next exercise, have a look at this notes page that is loaded up in a browser window:

atoms.alt: An HTML document entitled "My HTML Notes" displayed in a browser.

complex_prompt.text: Match each of the things from the above picture with the term that best describes it.

It's common to confuse  the `title`, `head`, and header elements.

Which HTML element would you use to do each of the following things?

concepts.text: To display the name of your page in the browser tab ...
To display the name of a section of your web page ...

correct_answer.text: ... use a heading element, like `h1` or `h2`.

concepts.text: To create a container for metadata about your page, such as the page's `title` ...

answers.text: ... use a heading element, like `h1` or `h2`.

complex_prompt.text: Which of these shows the typical structure of a web page?

concepts.text:
```html

My Page

Welcome to My Page

This is my page!

```

```html My Page

Welcome to My Page

This is my page!

```

complex_prompt.text: Each of these pieces of HTML is missing something. Can you pair the code with what's missing?

concepts.text:
```html My HTML Notes

These are my notes about HTML!

```

```html

These are my notes about HTML!

```

```html Welcome to My HTML Notes

These are my notes about HTML!

```

atoms.text:
At first, it can be hard to remember this basic page structure—what the different parts are and where they go. See if you can! Try building the basic HTML page structure in the workspace below.

Remember to include:
* A `head` element
* The doctype
* A `title` element
* An `html` element
* A `body` element

Trying to remember this structure will help solidify it in your brain, so put some effort into it! But if you get stuck, don't worry about—just look at the solution below the workspace.

## ⚠️ Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
----

## Solution **Note:** The `p` and `h1` elements aren't part of the basic structure; we just added them as an example of some content you might place in the `body`. ```html My HTML Notes

Welcome to My HTML Notes

These are my notes about HTML!

```

atoms.title: Intro to HTML: Validating HTML Documents

atoms.text:
### Try the validator! Take a look at the following HTML. How many error messages do you think the validator will give for it? ``` This is great HTML! Such a wonderful page.

``` Copy and paste it into the "Direct Input" tab of the validator at https://validator.w3.org/ .

question.prompt:
How many errors do you get? Enter the number of errors here.
>**Note:** The validator may also give you **warnings** as well as errors. This question is just asking about **errors** (don't count the warnings in your answer).

atoms.text:
### The validator is stricter

Web browsers are very _lenient_ about how they interpret HTML. They work around small errors and omissions. The quizzes you have seen in this lesson have been relatively lenient as well. The HTML validator is intentionally _stricter_ than actual browsers.

For instance, if you write an `img` element with no `alt` attribute, a typical browser will display it just fine. But the language requires the `alt` attribute to provide a textual description of an image; this helps search engines and also users with visual disabilities. By reporting a missing `alt` attribute as an error, the validator makes sure that valid HTML will be more accessible.

#### ... but it can't catch everything

The validator cannot tell whether you gave your document a _good_ title. It can't tell whether the `alt` attribute contains an _accurate_ description of the image. The validator won't notice if you wrote `<html lang="de">` (saying that your document is in German) on a document that is actually written in Korean. It is still up to you to make sure that your HTML says what you mean it to say.

## But what does it mean?!

You will definitely sometimes run into validation errors that you don't understand. This is a normal part of being a programmer, so it's important to develop skills for working through them!

When you do see an error that you're not sure about, here are a few things you can try:
* Copy and paste the error into your favorite **search engine**.
* Post the error to your **Study Group** and discuss it with other students and your mentors.
* Search **Knowledge** to see if someone has previously encountered this error. If they haven't, you can post a question about it yourself!

atoms.title: Validate your notes!
tasks: I've put my notes file into the validator.
I've corrected any errors that the validator gave me.
atoms.positive_feedback: Congratulations! You have a valid HTML file. You can use it to complete the upcoming lab!
atoms.description: Paste or upload your `notes.html` file into the validator. If it doesn't show any errors, great! If it does, use them as a checklist to improve your HTML syntax.

atoms.text:
# Woohoo!
You just finished your first full lesson on coding! We hope you enjoyed it. 🙂

When you click the **Next** button, you'll see a pop-up that will ask you to rate the lesson. After you select a rating, you'll also see a box where you can write any comments you want to share.

We're always looking for ways to make our lessons better, so please do leave us a note about your experience. **We absolutely _love_ feedback!** (And yes, we really do read what you write!)
